Water this plant sparingly to avoid root rot, allowing the soil to dry completely between waterings. During its active growing season in spring, increase watering frequency slightly to support stem and leaf growth, but always ensure the soil has good drainage. In the dormant summer months, reduce watering significantly, relying more on natural rainfall if possible. Overwatering can be detrimental, so monitor soil moisture closely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calochortus tolmiei thrives in environments that mimic its native open grasslands and woodlands, requiring full sun to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day during its growing season. If growing indoors or in areas with less sunlight, supplement with grow lights to ensure this requirement is met. While it can tolerate some shade, excessive shade may lead to weak growth and poor flowering. Position the plant where it can capture ample morning sunlight, reducing exposure during the peak afternoon heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Calochortus tolmiei isn't typically necessary, as these are bulbous plants with a natural lifecycle that includes dormancy. After blooming in late spring or early summer, allow the plant's foliage to yellow and die back naturally, which helps the bulb store nutrients for the next season. Remove any dead or diseased leaves gently by hand to prevent possible infections. Avoid cutting back green and healthy foliage, as this can hinder the plant's growth and development. Otherwise, while dormant, little maintenance is needed."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Tolmie's pussy ears","description":"Calochortus tolmiei is a North American species of flowering plant in the lily family known by the common names Tolmie star-tulip and pussy ears. Water the plant deeply once every week or every other week, allowing the soil to dry out between waterings. It’s essential not to overwater, as sitting in waterlogged soil can cause the bulbs to rot. During the winter months, reduce watering, as the plant's growth slows down. Providing a mulch layer can help retain soil moisture but avoid mulching too heavily near the bulb area to prevent excess moisture."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Allium lacunosum thrives in full sun, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight each day. Placing this plant in a bright, sunny location will encourage robust growth and stunning blossoms. If planted in a slightly shaded area, the plant may grow taller and lean towards the light, but lack of adequate sunlight can result in fewer or smaller blooms. Ensure it receives the necessary sunlight to mimic its natural habitat conditions and promote flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Allium lacunosum mainly involves removing dead flower heads and any yellowing leaves. After the flowering period, cut back the flower stalks to the base once they have turned brown, as this prevents energy being spent on seed production and encourages bulb strength. Allow the leaves to die back naturally before removal, as they photosynthesize and store food for the next growing season. Regular, light pruning helps maintain plant health and encourages fresh growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pitted onion","description":"Allium lacunosum is a species of wild onion known by the common name pitted onion. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10210,"attracts":["Birds"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus jeffreyi, commonly known as Jeffrey pine, prefers dry conditions once established, so it should be watered sparingly. It's best to water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out between watering sessions. This mimics its natural environment, which often has dry summers. Ensure good drainage to prevent root rot, as this pine does not tolerate waterlogged soils. Generally, watering every 2 to 3 weeks during the growing season, and less frequently during dormancy, should suffice. Adjust frequency based on local climate conditions and rainfall."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus jeffreyi thrives in full sunlight, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight per day. It is well-adapted to open, sunny locations and does not perform well in shaded or densely forested areas. Full sunlight helps the tree maintain its dense, pyramidal shape and promotes robust growth. If planted in an area with partial sun, ensure it receives maximum morning light to support its growth. Lack of sufficient sunlight can lead to sparse foliage, weak branches, and stunted growth, as the tree fails to photosynthesize efficiently."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus jeffreyi should be done sparingly. The best time to prune is during late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove dead or diseased branches to promote healthy growth. Avoid cutting into the main trunk or removing large branches unless necessary, as this can create wounds that are susceptible to pests and disease. If shaping is needed, do so minimally; removing up to one-third of the new candle growth can control size without harming the tree. Avoid heavy pruning, as the natural shape of Jeffrey pine is one of its defining characteristics."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Jeffrey pine","description":"Jeffrey pine (Pinus jeffreyi) also known as Jeffrey's pine, yellow pine and black pine, is a North American pine tree. Over-watering can lead to root rot, so it's important to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings. During the growing season, watering every two to three weeks is generally sufficient. If grown indoors or in a less sun-drenched area, consider supplementing with grow lights to meet its sunlight requirements. These species form the only restricted xerophyte species group in the genus Cucurbita. When watering, ensure the medium is just moist to the touch but not waterlogged, as this can promote mold that competes with or harms the fungus. Using artificial grow lights with lower intensity, suited for shade-loving plants, can be an effective way to provide consistent light without risking exposure to direct, potentially damaging sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"In the wild, Oudemansiella mucida does not require pruning because it is a fungus rather than a traditional plant. The process does not involve traditional pruning techniques, so handle with care to avoid damaging the mycelium underneath. Ensure to use sterile equipment to prevent contamination of the growth substrate."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"porcelain mushroom","description":"Oudemansiella mucida, commonly known as porcelain fungus, is a basidiomycete fungus of the Physalacriaceae family and native to Europe.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe"],"other_name":["porcelain mushroom"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Oudemansiella mucida"],"soil":["Decaying wood","Moist"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It is fairly drought-tolerant once established, but during the growing season, especially in spring and summer, it benefits from regular watering to promote healthy growth and bloom production. Ensure that the soil is well-draining to prevent waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. Water deeply but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry out slightly between waterings. Reduced watering is required in the fall and winter when the plant is dormant. Over-watering should be avoided as it can be detrimental to the plant's health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Gilia capitata thrives in full sunlight conditions, requiring at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight per day. It prefers open, sunny locations that replicate its native habitats, such as meadows and prairies, where there is ample sun. Although it can tolerate partial shade, optimal blooming occurs in full sun. When planted in less sunny spots, the plant may grow leggy or produce fewer flowers. Therefore, ensuring adequate sunlight is crucial for supporting robust growth and abundant flowering. When selecting a planting site, prioritize areas that receive consistent sunlight throughout the day."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Gilia capitata is generally straightforward, requiring minimal intervention. Deadheading spent blooms can encourage continuous flowering throughout the season. This involves simply snipping off the faded flowers at the base of the flower stalk to promote the growth of new blooms. Additionally, remove any dead or damaged foliage to maintain plant health and appearance. In the autumn, after the plant has finished flowering and the foliage begins to die back, you can cut the plant to ground level to tidy the garden and prepare it for winter, although this step is not strictly necessary."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"bluehead gilia","description":"Gilia capitata is a species of flowering plant in the phlox family known by the common names blue-thimble-flower, bluehead gilia, blue field gilia, and globe gilia. It grows in many habitats, especially in sandy or rocky soils.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["bluehead gilia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Gilia capitata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Avoid cutting into old wood with no green foliage, as Thuja may not regenerate from it. Always use sharp, clean tools to prevent disease spread and achieve precise cuts."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"northern whitecedar","description":"Thuja occidentalis, also known as northern white-cedar or eastern arborvitae, is an evergreen coniferous tree, in the cypress family Cupressaceae, which is native to eastern Canada and much of the north, central and upper Northeastern United States, but widely cultivated as an ornamental plant. Instead, focus on harvesting. If harvesting the conks for art or study, carefully cut the fruiting body off at the base where it meets the host. Gloves should be worn when handling to avoid damaging the spores or the delicate undersurface where the artist can create drawings. Regular removal of older conks can promote the health of the underlying mycelial network."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"artist's bracket","description":"Ganoderma applanatum (the artist's bracket, artist's conk or bear bread) is a bracket fungus with a cosmopolitan distribution.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Asia","North America","Europe"],"other_name":["artist's bracket"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Ganoderma applanatum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11320,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Brodiaea terrestris, commonly known as dwarf brodiaea, requires moderate watering. Ensure the soil remains consistently moist during its growing season, which is typically in spring and early summer. Reduce watering in the dormant period, as the plant prefers drier conditions at this time. Over-watering can lead to bulb rot, so allow the soil surface to dry out between waterings. It's crucial to use well-draining soil to prevent water-logging and enhance bulb health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Brodiaea terrestris thrives in full sun to partial shade. To achieve optimal growth and vibrant blooms, provide it with at least 6 hours of direct sunlight daily. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from intense sun. If grown in partial shade, it may produce fewer flowers. Ensuring the plant receives adequate sunlight is essential for healthy growth and flowering, especially in its active growing season during spring."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Brodiaea terrestris is minimal. Once the flowering period ends, you can cut back the flowering stalks to the base to tidy up the plant. Avoid cutting back the green foliage until it has yellowed and died back naturally, as this process helps the plant store energy in its bulbs for the next growing season. Removing dead or yellowed leaves can keep the plant looking its best and help prevent disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Dwarf Brodiaea","description":"Brodiaea terrestris, the dwarf brodiaea, is a species of plant in the genus Brodiaea that is native to California and Oregon.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California","Oregon"],"other_name":["Dwarf Brodiaea"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Bulb propagation"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Brodiaea terrestris"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10810,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Nothocalais cuspidata, commonly known as prairie false dandelion, prefers well-drained soils and moderate moisture conditions. It's adapted to dry prairie environments, so it's essential to avoid overwatering. During the growing season, water only when the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Reduce watering in the dormant months, ensuring the soil doesn't remain soggy to prevent root rot. If grown in pots, make sure there are proper drainage holes to avoid water accumulation, as the plant thrives best in conditions where water can drain away freely."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Nothocalais cuspidata thrives in full sunlight, similar to its natural prairie habitat. To ensure optimal growth, place the plant where it can receive at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day. If grown indoors, a south or west-facing window can provide adequate light. While the plant is tolerant of some shade, insufficient sunlight could result in leggy growth and fewer blooms. It's best to mimic its natural conditions by providing as much direct light as possible, while also keeping an eye on the plant for any signs of sunburn during periods of extreme heat."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Nothocalais cuspidata is minimal but can be done to maintain its appearance and encourage healthy growth. Remove any dead or damaged leaves regularly to prevent diseases. After the flowering period has concluded, you can deadhead spent flowers to tidy up the plant, though this step is not essential for its health. Since the plant doesn’t require much pruning, simply let it grow naturally, trimming only to remove unsightly parts. Avoid cutting too much of the foliage as this can stress the plant and reduce its ability to photosynthesize effectively."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"prairie false dandelion","description":"Nothocalais cuspidata, the prairie false dandelion, is a herbaceous perennial with yellow flowers and long slender leaves, native to the Great Plains.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["prairie false dandelion"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Nothocalais cuspidata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It thrives in environments where it receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day. While it can tolerate partial shade, placing it in a location with full sun will promote more vigorous growth and blooming. If indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window for optimal sunlight exposure. Be cautious of too much intense afternoon sun in very hot climates, as this can cause leaf scorching."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Gamochaeta purpurea is minimal and primarily involves removing dead or damaged leaves to maintain its appearance and health. If the plant becomes leggy, you can trim back the stems slightly to encourage more bushy growth. Pruning can be done at any time of the year, but it is best performed during the active growing season to avoid stress on the plant. Always use clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to minimize the risk of disease transmission."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Purple Cudweed","description":"Gamochaeta purpurea, the purple cudweed, purple everlasting, or spoonleaf purple everlasting, is a plant native to North America....","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Purple Cudweed"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Gamochaeta purpurea"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11025,"attracts":["Birds","Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Solanum dulcamara prefers consistently moist soil conditions, especially during its active growing seasons in spring and summer. It is important to water the plant regularly, ensuring that the soil remains moist but not waterlogged, as overly wet soil can lead to root rot. In drier periods or during high temperatures, increase watering frequency to maintain adequate soil moisture. During the dormancy phase in late fall and winter, reduce watering to allow the soil to slightly dry out between waterings, mimicking natural seasonal changes."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Solanum dulcamara thrives best in full sun to partial shade. It typically prefers a good amount of direct sunlight for at least 4-6 hours a day, which helps it produce vivid flowers and healthy foliage. In hotter climates, some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch and reduce water stress. However, too much shade may result in sparse flowering and weaker growth. It is adaptable to a variety of light conditions, but for optimal growth, ensure it receives ample sunlight regularly while protected from extreme heat conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solanum dulcamara is essential to encourage healthy growth and to prevent it from becoming too leggy or invasive. This should be done in early spring before new growth begins or after the plant has flowered in mid to late summer. Remove any dead, damaged, or weak stems, and thin out the plant to improve air circulation. Cut back overly long stems to a desired shape or size, which can also stimulate the production of side shoots. Regular pruning helps maintain the plant's health and enhances its ornamental appeal."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bittersweet nightshade","description":"Solanum dulcamara, also known as bittersweet, bittersweet nightshade, bitter nightshade, blue bindweed, Amara Dulcis, climbing nightshade, fellenwort, felonwood, poisonberry, poisonflower, scarlet berry, snakeberry, trailing bittersweet, trailing nightshade, violet bloom, or woody nightshade, is a species of vine in the potato genus Solanum, family Solanaceae. It is native to Europe and Asia, and widely naturalised elsewhere, including North America, where it is an invasive problem weed.","family":null,"flower_color":"Purple","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["bittersweet nightshade"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Fungal leaf spot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Solanum dulcamara"],"soil":["Moist","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Watering deeply once or twice a week should be sufficient, depending on the climate and weather conditions. A layer of mulch can help retain soil moisture and protect the roots from extreme temperatures. Ensure the soil drains well to prevent standing water around the roots."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Viburnum opulus thrives in full sun to partial shade. In contrast, in cooler climates, locating the plant in a full sun position can help maximize its blooming potential and overall vigor."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Viburnum opulus is essential to maintain its shape and health. Prune the plant in late winter or early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or diseased wood, and thin out any crowded branches to improve air circulation. It is also a good practice to prune after the plant has finished flowering to encourage new growth and more blooms. When pruning, make clean cuts close to the main stem and remove suckers or shoots that grow from the base to keep the plant tidy and prevent it from becoming too dense."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"guelder-rose","description":"...","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Red\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","Asia","North America"],"other_name":["guelder-rose"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Leaf beetles","Powdery mildew"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Viburnum opulus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12008,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Horkelia californica, commonly known as California horkelia, thrives in dry climates and has adapted to withstand drought. Water this plant sparingly, especially once it is established, as too much moisture can be detrimental. Ensure your soil has excellent drainage to prevent waterlogging and root rot. During the growing season, occasional watering may be required if natural rainfall is insufficient, but always allow the top layer of soil to dry out between waterings. During dormancy, reduce watering considerably, only providing moisture when absolutely necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Horkelia californica prefers full sun to partial shade conditions. Ideally, this plant should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to promote robust flowering and overall health. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can prevent the leaves from scorching and help the plant maintain moisture. However, in more temperate or high-altitude environments, full sun will enhance its growth and bloom. If planted in a location with less direct sunlight, expect slightly reduced flowering."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Horkelia californica involves removing dead or damaged foliage to encourage healthy growth and to maintain its natural shape. It is best to prune after the flowering season has ended, usually in late summer or early fall. Cut back any spent flower stems and foliage that appear lanky or diseased. Regularly remove any dead leaves at the base to prevent rot and pest infestations. Be cautious not to over-prune, as this can stress the plant, and always use sharp, clean tools to minimize the risk of transmitting diseases."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California horkelia","description":"Horkelia californica (syn: Potentilla californica), known by the common name California horkelia, is a species of flowering plant in the rose family.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["California"],"other_name":["California horkelia"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Horkelia californica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11214,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Chlorophyllum rhacodes, commonly known as the shaggy parasol, requires regular but not excessive watering. Ensure that the soil is kept consistently moist but not waterlogged, as overly wet conditions can promote root rot. Water the plant whenever the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Use room temperature water and aim to water in the early morning or late afternoon to allow any excess water on foliage to evaporate. Adjust the watering frequency depending on the humidity and temperature of the environment, as dryer climates may necessitate more frequent watering."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The shaggy parasol mushroom does not require direct sunlight to thrive. It prefers dappled or indirect light, similar to what it would experience on a forest floor. If kept indoors, place it in a location where it can receive bright, indirect sunlight. Direct exposure to harsh sunlight can cause dehydration and potential damage to the plant's delicate structure. If growing outdoors, choose a shaded or partially shaded spot that receives filtered light during the day. Monitor the plant for signs of sunburn or stress, and adjust its placement as necessary."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Chlorophyllum rhacodes is mostly about managing space and promoting healthy growth. Trim any dead or yellowing leaves at the base to encourage new growth and improve air circulation around the plant. Make cuts with clean, sharp scissors or pruning shears to prevent damage or disease. Inspect the plant regularly and remove any spent flowers or brown tips. This maintenance helps maintain a neat appearance and can prevent potential fungal infections by ensuring proper airflow. Prune during the plant's inactive growth period, typically in the cooler months."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Shaggy Parasol","description":"The Shaggy parasol is the common name for three closely related species of mushroom, Chlorophyllum rhacodes (or rachodes), C. olivieri and C. brunneum, found in North America, Europe and Southern Africa (the latter species is also found in Australia).","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Europe","North America"],"other_name":["Shaggy Parasol"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Chlorophyllum rhacodes"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11625,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Selaginella bigelovii, commonly known as Bigelow's spike-moss, prefers a consistently moist environment. Water the plant regularly, ensuring that the soil remains damp but not waterlogged. It's essential to avoid letting the soil dry out completely, as this plant is not drought tolerant. Instead of overhead watering, use a saucer method or bottom watering to prevent mold and mildew, as tender foliage can be sensitive to high humidity. Additionally, during warmer months, you might need to increase the frequency of watering, but ensure proper drainage to prevent root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Selaginella bigelovii thrives in partial shade to full shade environments. It is well adapted to indirect, diffused light conditions typically found in its native understory habitats. Exposure to direct sunlight can scorch the delicate fronds and dry out the plant too quickly. If grown indoors, place near a north or east-facing window where it can receive gentle morning light. In outdoor settings, ensure it's under the partial cover of taller plants or structures. Remember, maintaining a humid atmosphere is equally important to mimic its natural growing conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Selaginella bigelovii is minimal as the plant has a naturally low-growing and spreading habit. It's typically sufficient to trim away any dead, yellowing, or damaged fronds as they appear. This can help maintain the plant's appearance and encourage healthier growth overall. Pruning can be done with sharp, sterilized scissors or gardening shears to prevent disease spread. Regularly removing dead matter also helps avoid potential fungal growth. However, it is important not to over-prune, as these plants do not respond well to aggressive cutting back."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Bigelow's Spikemoss","description":"Selaginella bigelovii is a species of spikemoss known by the common names bushy spikemoss and Bigelow's spikemoss. It's crucial to allow the soil to dry out completely between waterings to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot. This should be done after the main flowering period to keep the plant neat and promote future blooms. This process, known as deadheading, not only tidies the plant but also stimulates more flower production. Trim back any leggy stems to maintain a compact shape and promote bushier growth. Regular maintenance pruning throughout the growing season will help keep this plant vigorous and attractive."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Smooth hawksbeard","description":"The smooth hawksbeard, Crepis capillaris, is a species in the dandelion tribe within the sunflower family, native to Europe. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10731,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Vinca major, commonly known as periwinkle, prefers moderate watering. Allow the soil to dry slightly between waterings to prevent waterlogging, as too much moisture can lead to root rot. During its active growing season in spring and summer, keep the soil consistently moist but not soggy. In fall and winter, reduce watering frequency, as the plant's growth slows down. The plant can tolerate short periods of drought, but regular moisture is ideal for healthy growth and optimal flowering. Adjust the watering schedule based on environmental conditions such as rainfall, humidity, and temperature."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Vinca major thrives in partial to full shade, making it ideal for ground cover in shaded or partially shaded areas. While it can tolerate full sun, especially in cooler climates, too much direct sunlight in hotter climates may result in scorched or yellowing leaves. Ideally, provide filtered sunlight or morning sun with afternoon shade. This plant is particularly adaptable, but optimal sunlight conditions will promote lush foliage and vibrant flowering. If grown indoors, place it near a bright window with indirect light to mimic its natural outdoor conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Vinca major helps to maintain its shape, encourage dense growth, and control its spread, as it can become invasive. Trim back the plant in early spring before new growth begins. Cut back any leggy or overgrown stems to promote bushier growth. Pinch off the tips of young shoots during the growing season to encourage a fuller plant. Additionally, remove any dead, damaged, or diseased stems throughout the year to keep the plant healthy. Regular pruning not only helps manage size but also encourages a more aesthetically pleasing form."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"greater periwinkle","description":"Vinca major, with the common names bigleaf periwinkle, large periwinkle, greater periwinkle and blue periwinkle, is species of flowering plant in the family Apocynaceae, native to the western Mediterranean. Adjust the light levels based on the plant’s reaction, ensuring that the leaves are not getting scorched."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cypripedium candidum mainly involves removing spent flowers and any damaged or dead leaves to maintain plant health and aesthetics. It is best to perform these tasks in the late fall or after the plant has gone dormant. Care should be taken not to damage the new shoots when pruning. Regular cleaning of old foliage can help prevent diseases and pest infestations. Always use clean, sharp tools to make clean cuts and minimize harm to the plant."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"small white lady's-slipper","description":"Cypripedium candidum, also known as small white lady's slipper or white lady's slipper, is a rare orchid of the Cypripedium genus.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["small white lady's-slipper"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slug"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Cypripedium candidum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Chalky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11215,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Chamaebatia foliolosa, commonly known as mountain misery, requires very little water once established, as it is a drought-tolerant plant native to California. During the first growing season, it should be watered regularly to help establish a deep root system. Afterward, occasional watering during prolonged dry periods is sufficient. Overwatering should be avoided, as this can lead to root rot. Always let the soil dry out between waterings, as the plant prefers well-drained soils and does not thrive in wet conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Mountain misery thrives in full sun to partial shade environments. Ideally, it should receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day to promote healthy growth. In areas with very hot climates, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from scorching. However, excessive shade might lead to sparse foliage and reduced vigor. Ensuring the plant has enough sunlight helps it maintain its dense, compact form and prevents it from becoming leggy. Adjust the exposure based on your local climate to keep the plant in optimal health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Chamaebatia foliolosa should be done primarily to maintain its shape and remove any dead or damaged branches. It is best to prune it in late winter or early spring before the new growth begins. Light pruning will suffice, as heavy pruning might stress the plant. Remove any crossing or crowded branches to improve air circulation and sunlight penetration within the plant. Always use clean and sharp pruning tools to avoid the spread of diseases and ensure a clean cut. Regular maintenance will help the plant achieve a healthy, bushy appearance."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Mountain Misery","description":"Chamaebatia foliolosa is a species of aromatic evergreen shrub in the rose family known by the common names mountain misery and bearclover. It is endemic to the mountains of California, where it grows in coniferous forests. The Miwok tribe's name for the plant was kit-kit-dizze. It was used as an herbal remedy for colds, coughs, rheumatism, chicken pox, measles, smallpox and other diseases.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["United States"],"other_name":["Mountain Misery"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Chamaebatia foliolosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Rocky","Gravelly"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11626,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pinus sabiniana, commonly known as the Grey Pine or Ghost Pine, is well-adapted to dry climates and requires minimal watering once established. Young trees should be watered regularly to help establish a strong root system, particularly during their first few years. Mature trees are drought-tolerant and usually do not require supplemental watering except during prolonged dry spells. Avoid overwatering as this can lead to root rot and other fungal diseases. Instead, focus on deep and infrequent watering that allows the soil to dry out between water applications."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus sabiniana thrives in full sunlight and requires at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight per day. It is well-suited for planting in open areas where it can receive ample sunlight. Inadequate sunlight can lead to poor growth and weaker trees. If planting in areas with partial shade, ensure the tree receives morning sunlight which is crucial for its growth and overall health. This pine is naturally found in open woodlands and foothills, indicating its preference and high adaptability to sunny and exposed environments."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Pinus sabiniana should be done with care to maintain its natural shape. Prune this pine in late winter to early spring while it is still dormant. Remove dead, damaged, or diseased branches to prevent the spread of pathogens and to promote healthy growth. Overwatering can harm plant health, so it is best to allow the soil to dry out between waterings. Young plants need more frequent, but light, watering to establish roots. Pay close attention to the local climate to determine the most appropriate watering schedule, and avoid letting the plant sit in waterlogged conditions, as this can lead to root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Bromus rubens thrives best in full sunlight, which means it should ideally receive at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight each day. If planted in heavily shaded areas, red brome may grow leggy and less vigorous."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Bromus rubens mainly involves the removal of old, dead, or diseased growth to encourage healthy new growth and prevent the spread of any infections. Deadheading, or removing spent inflorescences, can help manage unwanted self-seeding and keep the plant looking tidy."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Red Brome","description":"Bromus madritensis (also, B. matritensis) is a species of brome grass known by the common name compact brome.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Mediterranean region","Southern Europe","North Africa"],"other_name":["Red Brome"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["July"],"scientific_name":["Bromus rubens"],"soil":["Dry","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10213,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Pleurotus ostreatus, commonly known as the oyster mushroom, prefers a consistently moist environment. In cultivation, maintain high humidity levels around 80-90% to promote healthy growth. Mist the growing substrate lightly with water daily, ensuring not to saturate the substrate. Proper drainage is critical to avoid waterlogging, which can lead to contamination. If grown indoors or in containers, avoid using chlorinated water and instead use distilled or rainwater. Monitoring moisture levels is crucial; the substrate should remain slightly damp to the touch but not excessively wet. Consistent moisture helps support robust fruiting conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pleurotus ostreatus requires moderate lighting for optimal growth and is sensitive to strong, direct sunlight which can dry out the substrate and damage the delicate mycelium. When grown indoors, it can thrive under indirect natural light or with artificial light, providing around 12 hours of light and 12 hours of darkness for best results. A typical fluorescent light or a cool LED light can suffice. If growing outdoors, choose a shaded area free from direct sunlight or cover it with a cloth to diffuse light. Adequate light exposure is necessary for stimulating healthy mushroom development and fruiting cycles."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pleurotus ostreatus typically does not require pruning as it is a fungus rather than a vascular plant, and its cultivation focuses on harvesting rather than shaping. Instead, focus on harvesting mature mushrooms promptly to encourage continued growth and fruiting. Mushrooms are ready to harvest when their caps turn upwards but before the edges start to curl and dry out. Use a clean, sharp knife or scissors to cut the stem at the base, taking care not to disturb the substrate. Remove any decaying or dead mushrooms to reduce the risk of mold and contamination and to ensure a healthy cultivation environment."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Oyster Mushroom","description":"Pleurotus ostreatus, the oyster mushroom or oyster fungus, is a common edible mushroom. It was first cultivated in Germany as a subsistence measure during World War I and is now grown commercially around the world for food. It is related to the similarly cultivated king oyster mushroom. Oyster mushrooms can also be used industrially for mycoremediation purposes.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Europe","North America","Asia"],"other_name":["Oyster Mushroom"],"pest_susceptibility":["Mildew","Bacterial blotch"],"propagation":["Spore"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Pleurotus ostreatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Fertile"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

When dormant in the winter, reduce watering significantly to prevent oversaturation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Lilium canadense prefers partial to full sunlight, making it ideal for dappled shade environments or areas with morning sun and afternoon shade. Cut back the flower stalks to the base after blooming, but leave the leaves intact until they turn yellow and die back naturally. This allows the plant to photosynthesize and store nutrients for future growth. In late fall, tidy the plant by removing dead foliage to reduce pest and disease risk. Pruning should be done carefully to avoid damaging the main stem or bulb."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Canada lily","description":"Lilium canadense, commonly called either the Canada lily, wild yellow-lily, or the meadow lily, is a native of eastern North America. However, you can remove spent flowers to prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively, which also helps direct energy back to the bulb for next year’s growth. Allow the leaves to die back naturally, as they provide nourishment to the bulb for next year's bloom. Once the foliage has completely withered and turned yellow or brown, you can gently remove it. Avoid cutting green leaves as they are vital for photosynthesis and storing energy."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"white fawnlily","description":"Erythronium albidum, the white fawnlily or white trout lily, is a small herbaceous flowering plant in the lily family. In garden beds, manually remove clumps to control its spread. Ideally, a position with morning sun and afternoon shade is perfect to balance sun exposure and protection."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Cercis canadensis should primarily be done in late winter to early spring, before bud break. This helps in shaping the tree and removing any dead or diseased wood. It’s important to cut back branches that cross each other to improve air circulation, which helps in reducing disease risk. While pruning, maintain the tree’s natural shape as much as possible. After the flowers have bloomed, light pruning can be done to shape the tree if needed. Avoid heavy pruning during the growing season as it can stress the tree."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"eastern redbud","description":"Cercis canadensis, the eastern redbud, is a large deciduous shrub or small tree, native to eastern North America from southern Ontario, Canada south to northern Florida but which can thrive as far west as California. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11520,"attracts":["Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Prosopis glandulosa, commonly known as honey mesquite, is highly drought-tolerant and doesn't require frequent watering once established. However, young plants benefit from regular watering to help them establish a strong root system. During the first year, water deeply every two weeks in dry periods, allowing soil to dry out between waterings. Mature plants generally only need supplemental water during prolonged droughts. Overwatering should be avoided as it prefers well-draining soils and can suffer from root rot if the soil is too moist for extended periods. Monitoring natural rainfall can help determine when watering is necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Prosopis glandulosa thrives in full sun and requires at least six hours of direct sunlight per day to grow healthily. It is adaptable to various environmental conditions but performs best with full exposure as it mimics its native habitat conditions. A sunny location enhances flower and pod production, contributing to better reproduction and plant health. In areas where full sun may not be available all day, ensure the plant gets the maximum possible light, although it might grow more slowly or sparsely in too much shade."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Prosopis glandulosa is best done during the late winter when the tree is dormant to ensure less stress. Prune to remove dead, diseased, or crossing branches to promote a strong structure and healthy growth. Because of its spiny branches, protective gloves and clothing are recommended. Avoid heavy pruning as this can stimulate excessive growth of long, thorny shoots. If shaping is necessary, prune lightly to retain the tree's natural form. Regular removal of fallen pods and debris can also help in managing unwanted seedlings in the surrounding area."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"honey mesquite","description":"Prosopis glandulosa, commonly known as honey mesquite, is a species of small to medium-sized, thorny shrub or tree in the legume family (Fabaceae).","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Mexico","Southwestern United States"],"other_name":["honey mesquite"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Prosopis glandulosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11817,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"The Ficus carica, commonly known as the fig tree, prefers a consistent watering schedule. It's essential to keep the soil evenly moist, particularly when the plant is actively growing and producing fruit. During the growing season, water deeply but allow the top layer of soil to dry out slightly between waterings. In dormancy periods, such as winter, reduce watering frequency to prevent root rot, but do not let the soil dry out completely. Over-watering or under-watering can lead to stress and premature fruit drop, so monitoring the soil moisture is key."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ficus carica thrives in full sunlight and requires at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sun daily for optimal growth and fruit production. Ideally, position your fig tree in a south- or west-facing location where it can soak up the most light. In regions with very hot temperatures, some afternoon shade may be beneficial to prevent leaf scorch. Ensure the location is well-drained, as figs do not tolerate wet feet. If growing indoors, place the plant near a bright window, or supplement with grow lights if natural light is insufficient. Consistent sunlight exposure is essential for a healthy fig tree."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Ficus carica should be performed during the dormant season, usually in late winter. Begin by removing any dead, damaged, or diseased wood. Thin out the center of the tree to allow light and air to penetrate, which helps prevent fungus and allows the fruit to ripen more evenly. Consider cutting back the length of shoots to control the size of the tree and encourage bushier growth. It's important to maintain a balanced shape and remove any suckers that may appear around the base. Proper pruning promotes healthier growth and can increase fruit production."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common fig","description":"Ficus carica is an Asian species of flowering plant in the mulberry family, known as the common fig (or just the fig). It is the source of the fruit also called the fig, and as such is an important crop in those areas where it is grown commercially. Native to the Middle East and western Asia, it has been sought out and cultivated since ancient times, and is now widely grown throughout the world, both for...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Purple\"]","growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":"Autumn","leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western Asia","Mediterranean"],"other_name":["common fig"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids","Scale Insects"],"propagation":["Cutting","Seed Propagation","Layering Propagation"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Ficus carica"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11217,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Ceanothus thyrsiflorus, commonly known as California lilac, prefers well-drained soil and does not require frequent watering once established. Overwatering can lead to root rot, particularly in clay soils. During the first year, water regularly to help establish deep roots. Once mature, this drought-tolerant plant needs little additional watering; typically, rainfall will suffice. In areas with minimal rainfall, water deeply but infrequently during prolonged dry periods to encourage deep root growth and maintain health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Ceanothus thyrsiflorus thrives in full sun, which encourages bountiful blooms and healthy growth. Ideally, it should receive at least six hours of direct sunlight daily. While it can tolerate partial shade, especially in hotter climates, full sunlight ensures the best flowering and compact, dense growth. In areas with very high temperatures, providing some afternoon shade can prevent leaf scorch. However, too much shade can result in reduced flowering and a leggier plant habit."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Ceanothus thyrsiflorus is usually done to maintain shape and remove dead or damaged branches. Light pruning is preferred and can be done after flowering in late spring or early summer. Avoid cutting into old wood, as this plant does not regenerate well from older branches. Focus on thinning crowded areas to improve air circulation and remove any crossing or inward-growing branches. Proper pruning enhances the plant's natural shape and encourages more prolific blooming the following season."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"blueblossom","description":"Ceanothus thyrsiflorus, known as blueblossom or blue blossom ceanothus, is an evergreen shrub in the genus Ceanothus that is endemic to California. The term 'Californian lilac' is also applied to this and other varieties of ceanothus, though it is not closely related to Syringa, the true lilac.","family":null,"flower_color":"Blue","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["California","North America"],"other_name":["blueblossom"],"pest_susceptibility":["Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Ceanothus thyrsiflorus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10412,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Trillium erectum, commonly known as red trillium, prefers consistently moist but not waterlogged soil conditions. It thrives best in environments where the soil remains evenly damp, especially during its growing season in the spring. Water the plant whenever the top inch of soil feels dry to the touch. Ensure good drainage to prevent standing water, which can cause root rot. During dormancy in summer, the plant requires less water, but do not let the soil dry out completely. Mulching can help retain moisture and keep the roots cool."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Trillium erectum thrives in partial to full shade conditions. In nature, it is commonly found under the canopy of deciduous forests, where it receives filtered sunlight. The plant benefits from morning sun with afternoon shade or dappled sunlight throughout the day. Too much direct sunlight can scorch the leaves and hinder growth, while excessive shade may result in poor blooming. When planting, consider a spot that simulates its natural woodland habitat, ensuring it receives adequate light without overexposure to harsh sun rays."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Trillium erectum is generally minimal and primarily involves removing dead or damaged foliage. After the plant has finished blooming, you can cut back any dead flower stalks to maintain a tidy appearance. In the fall, when the leaves start to yellow and die back naturally, you can clean up the garden bed by gently removing the dead leaves. Be careful not to cut the plant back too early, as the leaves help to nourish the rhizomes through photosynthesis. Avoid excessive disturbance of the area as trilliums do not like to be moved."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"red trillium","description":"Trillium erectum, also known as red trillium, wake-robin, purple trillium, Beth root, or stinking Benjamin, is a species of flowering plant.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Eastern North America"],"other_name":["red trillium"],"pest_susceptibility":["Slug","Snail"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Trillium erectum"],"soil":["Acidic","Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11920,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Jaumea carnosa, commonly known as fleshy jaumea, thrives in saline environments, indicating its preference for moist to wet soil conditions. It should be watered consistently to maintain moderately wet soil, especially during dry periods. However, care should be taken to avoid waterlogging, as overly saturated soil can harm the roots. During growth periods, ensure the plant receives regular watering to support healthy growth, reducing frequency during dormant periods. It's best to use water with low salinity to avoid affecting nutrient uptake."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Jaumea carnosa prefers full sun to partial shade environments, mirroring its natural habitat in coastal regions. Position it in a spot where it receives at least 4 to 6 hours of sunlight daily for optimum growth. Full sun exposure enhances the plant's vigorous growth and robustness. However, in extremely hot regions, providing partial shade during the peak afternoon hours can prevent the leaves from scorching. Adjust its sunlight exposure based on whether it's in a container or in the ground to optimize its health."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Jaumea carnosa isn't usually necessary for its health, but it can help maintain its shape and remove any unhealthy parts. If needed, prune in the early spring before new growth starts. Remove any dead or damaged stems, cutting back to healthy tissue to encourage new growth. For aesthetic reasons, you can trim it to control its size and shape, ensuring even and tidy development. Always use clean, sharp tools to prevent disease transmission and give the plant the best chance to heal quickly."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Marsh Jaumea","description":"Jaumea carnosa, known by the common names marsh jaumea, fleshy jaumea, or simply jaumea, is a halophytic salt marsh plant native to the west coast of North America. It has succulent green leaves on soft pinkish-green stems, not unlike ice plant in appearance. Its flowers are yellow. It spreads by an extensive rhizome system.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Marsh Jaumea"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["March"],"scientific_name":["Jaumea carnosa"],"soil":["Well-drained","Sandy","Coastal"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11427,"attracts":["Pollinators"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Cypripedium arietinum, commonly known as the ram's-head lady's slipper, requires careful watering to mimic its natural habitat. During the growing season, from late spring to early summer, it is important to maintain consistently moist soil without allowing the roots to become waterlogged. Watering should be done gently to avoid disturbing the soil around the delicate root system. In winter, when the plant is dormant, watering should be reduced significantly, but do not allow the soil to dry out completely. Rainwater or distilled water is ideal to prevent buildup of salts and minerals from tap water."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"The ram's-head lady's slipper prefers partial shade to mimic its native woodland environment. It thrives in dappled sunlight, receiving indirect light throughout the day. Direct sunlight should be avoided, especially during the hottest parts of the day, as it can scorch the delicate foliage. Providing shade during midday can help protect the plant. In its natural habitat, this species often grows under the canopy of deciduous trees, which filter sunlight appropriately. Mimicking these conditions in a garden setting can create a conducive growing environment for this orchid, enhancing its flowering potential."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Cypripedium arietinum involves minimal intervention. Since it's a perennial herb, pruning is primarily focused on removing dead or damaged leaves and stems to promote healthy growth and prevent diseases. After the flowering season, cut back any withered flower stems to maintain plant aesthetics. Avoid cutting green, healthy leaves as they are essential for photosynthesis and growth. In autumn, once the plant has naturally died back, remove the decayed foliage to prepare it for dormancy. Using clean, sharp tools is important to prevent infection and facilitate smooth cuts."}],"care_level":"High","common_name":"Ram's-head Lady's Slipper","description":"Cypripedium arietinum, the ram's head lady's slipper, is a rare orchid that grows in lightly shaded areas with calcareous soils. It is characteristic of the alvars around the Great Lakes in North America, as well as in New England. In Canada, it is found from Quebec to Saskatchewan, plus an isolated population in Nova Scotia, where it grows on gypsum based soils, 330 km away from the nearest population in Maine.","family":null,"flower_color":"Red","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Ram's-head Lady's Slipper"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["September"],"scientific_name":["Cypripedium arietinum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10322,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Leucocrinum montanum, commonly known as star lily or sand lily, thrives in dry, rocky environments and has low water requirements. This perennial plant does best when its soil is allowed to dry out between watering sessions. Water the plant thoroughly, but infrequently, allowing the soil to dry completely to mimic its natural arid conditions. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other issues, so it's crucial to err on the side of underwatering rather than overwatering. Providing the plant with deep, infrequent watering will encourage deep root growth and a healthy, drought-tolerant plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Leucocrinum montanum is a sun-loving plant that thrives best in full sunlight. For optimal growth, it requires at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. The plant is well-adapted to high-altitude regions and can grow in semi-shaded conditions; however, abundant sunlight is crucial for robust flowering and healthy growth. When grown in a garden, place it in a location that receives unobstructed sunlight throughout the day. In partial or full shade, flowering may be reduced, and the plant can become leggy as it stretches for sunlight. This plant is well-suited to rock gardens and open, sunny areas."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Leucocrinum montanum is generally minimal, as this plant maintains a neat, clumping growth habit. The primary focus of pruning should be to remove any dead or damaged leaves to keep the plant looking tidy and to prevent any potential disease problems. Prune out spent flower stalks after blooming has finished to help improve the plant’s appearance and to encourage new growth. It's best to trim the plant in early spring or after its blooming cycle has ended. Remember to use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant tissues."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"common starlily","description":"Leucocrinum montanum, commonly known as the sand lily, common starlily or mountain lily, is the only species in the monotypic genus Leucocrinum, placed in the family Asparagaceae, and subfamily Agavoideae. It is native to the western United States, primarily in the Rocky Mountains and the Great Basin.","family":null,"flower_color":"White","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["Western United States"],"other_name":["common starlily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["June"],"scientific_name":["Leucocrinum montanum"],"soil":["Well-drained","Dry","Rocky"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

{"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10734,"attracts":["Bees","Butterflies"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Acacia dealbata, commonly known as the silver wattle, is a drought-resistant plant and generally does not require frequent watering. During the growing season in spring and summer, water the plant moderately, allowing the top inch of soil to dry out between waterings. In the cooler months, reduce watering significantly. It is important to avoid waterlogging, as this can lead to root rot. Ensure that the soil has good drainage, particularly if the acacia is planted in a pot. In climates with high rainfall, additional watering may not be necessary."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Acacia dealbata thrives in full sunlight and should be positioned in a location that receives at least 6 hours of direct sunlight per day for optimal growth. Although it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight may lead to reduced flowering and a leggier, less compact growth habit. In regions with extremely hot summers, some afternoon shade may protect the plant from intense heat. When grown indoors, place the Acacia near a south-facing window to provide ample light, or consider supplemental lighting if natural light is inadequate."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Acacia dealbata is typically done to maintain its shape and remove any dead or diseased branches. The best time to prune is after the flowering season, which occurs in late winter to early spring. This helps stimulate new growth and prepares the plant for the next bloom. Cut back any overgrown or crossing branches to encourage a more open structure, which promotes air circulation. Avoid heavy pruning, as this can stress the plant; instead, focus on light, regular trims to maintain its natural shape and vigor."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Silver wattle","description":"Acacia dealbata (known as silver wattle, blue wattle or mimosa) is a species of Acacia, native to southeastern Australia in New South Wales, Victoria, Tasmania, and the Australian Capital Territory and widely introduced in Mediterranean, warm temperate, and highland tropical landscapes.","family":null,"flower_color":"Yellow","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["Australia"],"other_name":["Silver wattle"],"pest_susceptibility":["Fungal leaf spot","Root rot"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["April"],"scientific_name":["Acacia dealbata"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

Once the leaves have yellowed and withered, they can be gently removed by cutting them back to the ground. Regular deadheading and cleaning up will keep the plant tidy and encourage better growth and blooms next season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Garden Grape-hyacinth","description":"Muscari armeniacum is a bulbous plant of the genus Muscari with basal, simple leaves and short, flowering stems. The flowers are purple, blue (with a white fringe), white (var. \"Album\") or pale pink (var \"Pink Sunrise\") and the plants are usually 15 centimetres (6 in) tall. Adequate sunlight is crucial for the plant to produce its characteristic vibrant yellow flowers."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Solidago spathulata involves removing spent flowers and any dead or damaged stems to promote healthy growth and an aesthetically pleasing appearance. After the flowering period, typically in late summer or early fall, trim back the plant to encourage a more compact form and to prevent excessive spreading. It's also beneficial to cut the plant down to about 6 inches above the ground in late winter to early spring before new growth begins. This will help renew the plant and stimulate vigorous blooming in the upcoming season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"coast goldenrod","description":"Solidago spathulata, the coast goldenrod or dune goldenrod, is a North American species of goldenrod in the sunflower family. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":11712,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Panus conchatus, often found growing in natural settings, does not require traditional watering as it is a fungus. In cultivation, ensure its substrate stays moist but not waterlogged. Use a spray bottle to mist the substrate regularly, maintaining a consistently damp environment. Avoid direct watering, as excessive moisture can lead to mold and rot, potentially harming the fungus. The humidity level should be relatively high to mimic natural conditions. Always allow some air exchange to prevent stagnation."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Panus conchatus does not require direct sunlight. Instead, it thrives in shaded environments typical of its natural habitats, such as under trees or in forested areas. In a cultivation setting, provide indirect light or diffuse light conditions. Avoid direct sunlight, as it can dry out the substrate and harm the fungus. An artificial light source that mimics the dappled light of a forest understory can be effective. Maintaining the appropriate light conditions is crucial for encouraging growth and fruiting. Maintain cooler temperatures to mimic natural conditions."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not applicable to Panus conchatus as it is a fungus rather than a plant. Instead, focus on cleaning. Regularly remove any decaying or dead material around the fungus to prevent contamination and pest infestations. Ensure that your cultivation area is clean and free of competing fungi or bacteria. This proactive management ensures healthy growth and prevents diseases that may arise from decaying material. Keep the environment dry enough to prevent mold while ensuring adequate moisture for the fungus itself."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Lilac oysterling","description":"Panus conchatus, commonly known as the lilac oysterling, is an inedible species of mushroom that occurs throughout the Northern Hemisphere. Its fruitbodies are characterized by a smooth, lilac- or tan-colored cap, and decurrent gills. The fungus is saprophytic and fruits on the decomposing wood of a wide variety of deciduous and coniferous trees. Despite being a gilled species, phylogenetic analysis has shown it is closely related to the pored species found in the family Polyporaceae.","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":"Summer","leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe"],"other_name":["Lilac oysterling"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":[],"pruning_month":["August"],"scientific_name":["Panus conchatus"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

In general, if the plant is located in a sunny and well-ventilated area, watering once or twice a week should suffice, reducing the frequency during cooler months. However, it can also handle some light shade during particularly hot summer afternoons."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Achillea ptarmica is essential for keeping the plant healthy and encouraging bushier growth. Deadhead spent flowers regularly to promote the development of new blooms and prolong the flowering period. In late autumn or early spring, trim back old or dead stems to ground level to tidy up the plant and stimulate new growth. Removing weak or straggly stems helps maintain a neat appearance. Occasionally, thinning out older, woody growth in the center of the plant can improve air circulation, reducing the risk of disease."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Sneezewort","description":"Achillea ptarmica (sneezewort, sneezeweed, bastard pellitory, European pellitory, fair-maid-of-France, goose tongue, sneezewort yarrow, wild pellitory, white tansy) is a European species of herbaceous perennial flowering plant in the genus Achillea. Its contorted, pubescent pods give rise to its common name \"prickly caterpillar\". As it is a fungus, it does not require traditional watering like plants do. Instead, its growth is dependent on the moisture content of the wood it inhabits. Ensure the tree or logs are in a location with stable moisture to provide ideal conditions."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Daedalea quercina thrives in environments that support the growth of its host, typically oak trees, and is often found in shaded areas, such as forests or woodlands where its woody hosts reside. While sunlight is not directly needed for the fungus itself, which doesn't perform photosynthesis, the moisture conditions influenced by the shaded environment can be pivotal in its growth. Therefore, maintaining a shaded, humid environment that mimics forest conditions will provide the best support for Daedalea quercina's natural development."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning is not relevant to Daedalea quercina since it is a fungus, not a plant. Instead of pruning, management may involve controlling its spread if it is causing unwanted decay on valuable living trees or timbers. This can involve removing infected wood and managing environmental conditions that favor its growth, such as excessive moisture. If growing it intentionally, ensure that the host wood remains in optimal condition without interference. Observing natural decay cycles without intervention is typically the best approach unless decay control on living trees is necessary."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Oak mazegill","description":"Daedalea quercina is a species of mushroom in the order Polyporales, and the type species of the genus Daedalea. It is found in Europe, Asia, Northern Africa and Australasia. While it can tolerate partial shade, insufficient sunlight can result in leggy growth and reduced flowering, so balance is key."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Trifolium depauperatum is generally minimal since it's a low-growing, delicate plant. Regularly remove any dead or withered foliage to promote healthy new growth and to maintain air circulation around the plant. After harvesting, remove any debris or dead material to prevent mold and pests. Regularly check on the growth medium and remove any mushrooms that are showing signs of rot or mold to maintain a healthy environment for remaining fungi."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"pig's ears","description":"Gomphus clavatus, commonly known as pig's ears or the violet chanterelle, is an edible species of fungus in the genus Gomphus native to Eurasia and North America. The upper surface or cap is orangish-brown to lilac, while the lower spore-bearing surface, the hymenium, is covered in wrinkles and ridges rather than gills...","family":null,"flower_color":null,"flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Low","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":null,"maintenance":"Moderate","origin":["North America","Europe","Asia"],"other_name":["pig's ears"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Spore Propagation"],"pruning_month":["October"],"scientific_name":["Gomphus clavatus"],"soil":["Loamy","Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

During the first few years after planting, water regularly to help the tree establish a strong root system. Once mature, the Bishop Pine is relatively drought-tolerant and should only be watered during extended dry periods or droughts. Overwatering can lead to root rot and other fungal problems. Ensure the soil is allowed to dry out slightly between watering, especially in clay soils which retain moisture longer."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Pinus muricata thrives best in full sun conditions, requiring at least six hours of direct sunlight each day. Consider the surrounding landscape to prevent shadows or encroach on its access to full sunlight."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Pinus muricata should generally be minimal. It is best performed in late winter or early spring before new growth begins. Remove any dead, diseased, or damaged branches to maintain tree health. Thin out crowded branches to improve air circulation, which can help reduce the risk of disease. Avoid excessive pruning, as this can stress the tree and lead to poor growth. For young trees, structural pruning can help establish a strong central leader and well-spaced branches, critical for future growth and stability."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"bishop pine","description":"The bishop pine, Pinus muricata, is a pine with a very restricted range: mostly in California, including several offshore Channel Islands, and a few locations in Baja California, Mexico. Management involves monitoring the growth and health of the fruiting bodies for any signs of contamination or decay. When cultivating, it’s more about maintaining a clean environment and proper substrate preparation than routine pruning. Cleaning the growing area and ensuring optimal air circulation can help prevent unwanted mold or bacterial growth."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"turkey-tail","description":"Trametes versicolor – also known as Coriolus versicolor and Polyporus versicolor – is a common polypore mushroom found throughout the world. During the growing season, it is important to ensure that the plant receives enough water, especially during dry periods. It is best to water early in the morning or late in the afternoon to prevent rapid evaporation and reduce the risk of fungal diseases. Be cautious not to overwater, as this can lead to root rot. Allow the top layer of the soil to dry out slightly between waterings to find the right balance for this resilient plant."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Calendula arvensis thrives in full sunlight and should ideally receive at least 6 hours of direct sunlight each day. While it can tolerate partial shade, optimal flowering and overall health are best achieved in bright, sunny locations. In regions with extremely hot summers, providing some afternoon shade can help prevent the flowers and leaves from scorching. When grown indoors or in areas with less intense sunlight, ensuring adequate light exposure by placing the plant near a south or west-facing window can help maintain its lush growth and vibrant blossoms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Calendula arvensis is mainly about deadheading, which involves removing spent flowers to encourage the plant to produce more blooms. This process should be done regularly throughout the blooming season. You can simply pinch or cut off the faded flowers just above a set of leaves or a new bud. To maintain the shape and vigor of the plant, you may trim back overgrown stems, but this is typically not necessary as the plant has a naturally compact growth habit. Pruning encourages bushier growth and more vibrant flowering."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"field marigold","description":"Calendula arvensis is a species of flowering plant in the daisy family known by the common name field marigold. It can tolerate partial shade but may produce fewer flowers and weaker stems with less sunlight. If grown indoors, place the plant near a south or west-facing window where it can receive ample light.
