It prefers moist soil, so it is essential to water it regularly to maintain even soil moisture, especially during dry spells. However, avoid overwatering as it can lead to root rot—ensure the soil has good drainage to prevent waterlogging. Mulching around the plant can help retain soil moisture. During the plant's dormant phase in winter, reduce watering frequency, but do not let the soil completely dry out."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Aralia californica thrives in partial to full shade conditions. While it can tolerate some sunlight, it prefers dappled or indirect light and does best in locations that receive morning sun with afternoon shade or under the canopy of taller trees. Too much direct sunlight can scorch the leaves, so it's important to provide protection from harsh midday and afternoon sun. In hotter climates, ensure the plant is shaded during peak sun hours to maintain its lush foliage and prevent stress."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning of Aralia californica should be carried out in late winter or early spring, before new growth begins. Remove any dead or damaged stems, as well as any that are overcrowded, to improve air circulation and promote healthy growth. Thinning out the older stems can encourage more vigorous growth in the younger stems. Since this plant can grow quite large, pruning can also help keep its size manageable and shape more attractive. Regularly deadhead spent flowers to encourage further blooming and maintain overall tidiness."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"California Spikenard","description":"Aralia californica, known by the common name elk clover though not actually a clover, is a large herb in the family Araliaceae, the only member of the ginseng family native to California and southwestern Oregon. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":10525,"attracts":["Birds","Bees"],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Populus deltoides, or the eastern cottonwood, requires a considerable amount of water due to its preference for wet, nutrient-rich environments. It thrives best when planted near a constant water source or in deep soils that maintain moisture well. During dry spells or if planted away from water bodies, ensure regular watering to keep the soil moist, especially in its early years of growth. It's crucial to avoid waterlogging the soil, as this can harm the roots. Throughout its growing season, consistent watering will support its rapid growth and overall health."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Eastern cottonwood trees require full sunlight to grow optimally. They thrive in open areas where they can receive a minimum of six hours of direct sunlight per day. These trees are often found in floodplains and along rivers where there's little shade competition, which contributes to their fast growth rate. When planting Populus deltoides, choose a site with ample exposure to sunlight and space, away from structures and other plants that may cast shadows. Adequate sunlight ensures vigorous growth and the avoidance of legginess or weak branches due to insufficient light."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Populus deltoides is primarily conducted to manage its size and shape, as well as to remove any diseased or dead branches. It's best to prune during the dormant winter months to minimize stress and infection risk. Remove any branches that rub together or overcrowd the canopy to improve air circulation and light penetration. Focus on creating a sturdy, central leader when the tree is young, which aids in its structural integrity. Regular inspection for broken or weak branches, especially after storms, is essential to maintain the tree’s overall health."}],"care_level":"Medium","common_name":"Eastern Cottonwood","description":"Populus deltoides, the eastern cottonwood or necklace poplar, is a cottonwood poplar native to North America, growing throughout the eastern, central, and southwestern United States, the southernmost part of eastern Canada, and northeastern Mexico. It is a eudicot.","family":null,"flower_color":"Green","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":"[\"Brown\"]","growth_rate":"High","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"High","origin":["North America"],"other_name":["Eastern Cottonwood"],"pest_susceptibility":["Leaf Beetle","Borers","Aphids"],"propagation":["Seed Propagation","Cutting"],"pruning_month":["February"],"scientific_name":["Populus deltoides"],"soil":["Well-drained","Loamy","Sandy"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

It prefers well-draining soil and should be watered deeply but infrequently to allow the soil to dry out between watering sessions. Overwatering can lead to root rot, so ensure that the plant is not sitting in water. During the active growing season in spring, you may need to water slightly more often, but generally, rainfall in its native regions should suffice for its needs."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Phacelia fremontii thrives in full sun to partial shade. It is suited for open environments and can tolerate a good amount of direct sunlight. However, in extremely hot regions, providing some afternoon shade can help protect the plant from the intense midday sun, which can be too harsh. Ensuring it has ample light during the day will support its growth and lead to more prolific blooming. In its natural habitat, it enjoys the wide open spaces where sun exposure is abundant, making it a versatile plant for various garden settings."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning for Phacelia fremontii is usually not necessary as it is a low-maintenance wildflower. However, deadheading or removing spent flowers may promote a longer blooming season and prevent the plant from self-seeding excessively. If the plant becomes leggy or if you’re managing its spread, you can trim it back after blooming. Be sure to use clean, sharp tools to avoid damaging the plant. Pruning should be done with care to maintain the plant's natural shape and to encourage healthy growth."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Frémont's Phacelia","description":"Phacelia fremontii (Frémont's phacelia) is a flowering plant in the family Boraginaceae native to the southwestern United States. {"type":"json_schema","json_schema":{"id":12016,"attracts":[],"care_guides_details":[{"type":"watering","description":"Amaryllis belladonna, commonly known as the Belladonna Lily or Naked Lady, requires careful watering. During the flowering period, keep the soil slightly moist but not waterlogged to support blooming. Once it finishes flowering and begins its dormant period, usually in late summer, reduce watering significantly. Allow the soil to dry out between waterings, as too much moisture during dormancy can cause rot. Begin watering again when new leaves start to emerge in late winter or early spring. Ensure the pot has good drainage to prevent water accumulation and root rot."},{"type":"sunlight","description":"Amaryllis belladonna thrives in full sunlight to partial shade. Ideally, it should receive at least 6-8 hours of direct sunlight daily for optimal blooming. Plant it in a location where it can bask in full morning sun but have some protection from the intense afternoon heat, especially in hotter climates. If you're growing it indoors, place it near a south or west-facing window that receives abundant light. Insufficient sunlight may lead to reduced flower production and leggy growth. Providing the right balance of sunlight will result in healthy, robust blooms."},{"type":"pruning","description":"Pruning Amaryllis belladonna primarily involves cleaning up dead or yellowing foliage. You should wait until the foliage has completely died back in the autumn before trimming it down to the base. This allows the plant to store energy for the next blooming season. Avoid cutting live green leaves as they are essential for photosynthesis. Also, remove spent flower stalks after the blooms fade to encourage healthy growth and prevent pests or disease. Routine pruning enhances the plant's appearance and health, ensuring vibrant blooms the following season."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Belladonna Lily","description":"Amaryllis belladonna, (Jersey lily, belladonna-lily, naked-lady-lily, March lily) is a plant species native to Cape Province in South Africa but widely cultivated as an ornamental. It is reportedly naturalized in many places: Corsica, Portugal, the Azores, Madeira, the Canary Islands, Zaire, Ascension Island, Australia, New Zealand, Mexico, Cuba, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Chile, California, Texas, Louisiana, and the Juan Fernández Islands.","family":null,"flower_color":"Pink","flowering_season":false,"fruit_color":null,"growth_rate":"Moderate","harvest_season":null,"leaf_color":["Green"],"maintenance":"Low","origin":["South Africa"],"other_name":["Belladonna Lily"],"pest_susceptibility":[],"propagation":["Bulb","Seed Propagation"],"pruning_month":["November"],"scientific_name":["Amaryllis belladonna"],"soil":["Well-drained"],"watering_period":"Morning"}}

If the plant starts to become too leggy or spindly, prune back the stems to promote bushier growth. Pruning is best done in early spring before new growth begins, ensuring to cut just above a leaf node. Avoid heavy pruning during the flowering season to maximize blooms."}],"care_level":"Easy","common_name":"Red Vetchling","description":"Lathyrus cicera is a species of wild pea known by the common names red pea, red vetchling and flatpod peavine.
